docs.lead_paragraph: Public health officials are now encouraging women to make sure they are in optimal health well in advance of a pregnancy.

headline.main: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late
headline.print_headline: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late

docs.snippet: Public health officials are now encouraging women to make sure they are in optimal health well in advance of a pregnancy.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, women have had it drummed into them that prenatal care is the key to having a healthy baby, and that they should see a doctor as soon as they know they are pregnant. But by then, it may already be too late. Public health officials are now encouraging women to make sure they are in optimal health well in advance of a pregnancy to reduce the risk of preventable birth defects and complications. They have recast the message to emphasize not only prenatal care, as they did in the past, but also what they are calling ''preconception care.''

headline.main: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late

docs.abstract: Many medical experts say that prepregnancy efforts are critical in having healthy baby; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends 10 specific measures along with prepregnancy checkups for women who may become pregnant; some say that women should maintain suggested prepregnancy health standards throughout reproductive years; drawing (M)
